issues.title: Should we expose the "SLH-DSA Hash-based Signature Algorithm Overview" section?
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
I added a "SLH-DSA Hash-based Signature Algorithm Overview" section copied from draft-ietf-lamps-cms-sphincs-plus but it is commented out in the markdown.

In my opinion, our draft should contain this section and it should be removed from draft-ietf-lamps-cms-sphincs-plus, which should reference our draft more.  But that's something to decide among the authors of both drafts, and so I don't want to make any changes to this text until that is decided, so that the texts don't get out of sync.

If we use the text, @BashiriK had some comments on it in #1 which can be addressed when we add the text:
https://github.com/x509-hbs/draft-x509-slhdsa/pull/1/files#r1494667760
https://github.com/x509-hbs/draft-x509-slhdsa/pull/1/files#r1494674721
https://github.com/x509-hbs/draft-x509-slhdsa/pull/1/files#r1494676398
https://github.com/x509-hbs/draft-x509-slhdsa/pull/1/files#r1494726908

issues.title: SHA2 Parameters
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
Did we decide to leave out SHA2-parameters for level III and V due to the discussion on the forum? Is it really decided in that way? If yes, I missed that.

_Originally posted by @BashiriK in https://github.com/x509-hbs/draft-x509-slhdsa/pull/1#discussion_r1494678234_

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body:
These are the parameters from draft-ietf-lamps-cms-sphincs-plus.  Justification is in https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/4sfCKyRYmFWa6L2-R6zH5BBPyNw/

If our draft is adopted we can reopen this issue as that discussion thread occurred before FIPS205-ipd was published.

_Originally posted by @danvangeest in https://github.com/x509-hbs/draft-x509-slhdsa/pull/1#discussion_r1498944614_

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: We are using all the FIPS205-ipd OIDs.

issues.title: Say something about reduced security when many many signatures are created
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body: The security of SLH-DSA slowly reduces below the target levels when more than 2^64 signatures have been created.  While this is not a practical number of signatures, we should still mention something about this fact in the Security Considerations section.  And maybe point out that if lower signature limit parameter sets are produced in the future, real-world use cases would have to be considered.

comments.author: fluppe2
comments.body:
I think the #signatures discussion should be left out as it doesn't help an implementer but rather poses confusion. This draft should define how to use SLH-DSA in X.509 and point to FIPS205 for the general security considerations.

Also I am unsure about the benefit of pointing towards a future discussion around the reduced number of signatures version of SPHINCS+. I think that might again rather confuse than help.

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: agreed

issues.title: SHA2 vs SHAKE, fast vs small
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
Explain the differences between parameter sets with sha2 vs shake, fast vs small.

From John Mattson:
    If you explain the "fast" parameter sets, please describe that they have much slower verification than the "small" parameter sets.

issues.title: Use in PKCS#10, CMP, OCSP?
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body: From John Mattsson: "For 5G use cases, I would strongly like the document to also cover use of SLH-DSA in RFC 2986 (PKCS #10), RFC 4210 (CMP), and RFC 6090 (OCSP)."

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: Unclear what John wants, seeing as we use similar language as many other RFCs.

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: I've emailed John for clarification.  Will find him at IETF 120 / mention needing clarification for this during the presentation if he doesn't respond.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: Note we got the same comment for ML-DSA; see [link](https://github.com/lamps-wg/dilithium-certificates/issues/10).

issues.title: Hash-SLH-DSA OIDs
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
Once NIST publishes FIPS205, decide what to do about pure vs predigest mode.  If we only support pure mode, add this text to the introduction:

> The final version of {{FIPS205}} is expected to define two signature modes: pure mode and predigest mode.  This document only specifies the use of pure mode with X.509 certificates and CRLs.

comments.author: fluppe2
comments.body:
NIST assigned OIDs to the parameter sets of the "pure" version of SLH-DSA and specific "pre-hash" combinations. See https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/computer-security-objects-register/algorithm-registration

Would it be better to include the "pre-hash" versions that have OIDs assigned for the sake of completeness?

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body:
The WG has been trying to curtail OID explosions.

That said, they may become necessary in X.509, see https://github.com/lamps-wg/dilithium-certificates/pull/31#issuecomment-2441892740

We can wait for that discussion to occur and the fallout from it.  However, because CMS has the signedAttributes feature, predigest mode isn't really necessary because the signedAttributes encoding will be relatively small.

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body:
While the WG determined that they do not want HashML-DSA because ML-DSA can have the message representative calculated by a different module (outside an HSM for example), this is not possible for SLH-DSA because it does a dual-pass.  The WG still thinks that HashSLH-DSA is not necessary for use by CA certificates, but we can't control what will be done by EE users, so during the presentation I said that we will add a section specifying HashSLH-DSA OIDs for use in SPKI of end-entity certificates.

There is also a desire to prune the OIDs, but I think we should just offer all them all first and then if people complain hard and offer suggestions, reduce the list.

issues.title: To be Explicit or Implicit?
issues.author: seanturner
issues.body: Settle on whether ASN.1 module should be implicit or explicit.

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: By sheer force of numbers, it'll be IMPLICIT.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: You can go ahead and close this one out based on [this](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/-zua7zlQ-0QBUcyQta3EKgqp7u0/).

pulls.title: Initial draft
pulls.author: danvangeest
pulls.body: Strongly based on lamps-dilithium-certificates and lamps-cms-sphincs-plus

comments.body: Though of negligible size, but there is also a randomizer included in the signature.

Above the hypertree part of SLH-DSA was separated from the FORS part. However, here it is written that "The parameters of the SLH-DSA hypertree include [...] the number of FORS trees". I would change it to 
"The parameters of SLH-DSA include ...".
My opinion: If we include the hash function as a paramter of the scheme, we should also include "small vs. fast" as a parameter.
Did we decide to leave out SHA2-parameters for level III and V due to the discussion on the forum? Is it really decided in that way? If yes, I missed that.
My optinion: This paragraph belongs to the section "SLH-DSA Hash-based Signature Algorithm Overview"

pulls.title: Draft update
pulls.author: danvangeest
pulls.body:
- Fix encoding text for public and private keys
- Separate ASN.1 module and add PublicKeys and PublicKeys lists
- Security Considerations
- Sizes table

comments.body: Here we can give reference to the new paper of my friend Markku Saarinen who suggests further recommendations and, moreover, provides some insights into side-channel resistant implementation of SLH-DSA.
https://eprint.iacr.org/2024/367

reviews.author: exception42
reviews.body: Agree with Kaveh to maybe add more references to fault attacks. Otherwise I agree with the changes.

Remove Private Key section as the private key encoding is specified in cms-sphincs-plus draft.

pulls.title: Explain that fast parameter sets are actually slower at verification
pulls.author: danvangeest

pulls.title: FIPS version
pulls.author: danvangeest
pulls.body:
- NIST OIDs
- Private Key Encodings
- More generally PKIX instead of certificates + CRLs
- More like RFC 8410 than dilithum-certificates
- Examples

comments.body: Is there a doubling of "are used" in "are used for signatures as are used for public keys"?

```suggestion
The security considerations of {{RFC5280}} apply accordingly.
```

reviews.author: fluppe2
reviews.body:
LGTM

Just some minor editorial comments that should be checked prior to merging.

comments.body: That is fine in English, I think it's the "in {{sec-alg-ids}}" that makes it awkward and isn't necessary so I'll remove that.

reviews.author: BashiriK
reviews.body:
I am disappointed from myself, because this remark should have came from me, since Markku and me spent a lot of time thinking about fault attacks. However, I like the new version, thank you. 

I think, for me, the reference [SLotH] did not work, but I did not give my best to find out what the problem was. So I think, the error is on my side.

The intended application for the key is indicated in the keyUsage certificate extension; see {{Section 4.2.1.3 of RFC5280}}. ```

> Some of the refs looked off. Hopefully, this will help the editor's version generate.

@seanturner , your PR failed to build so I made/reverted some changes.
"DOI.10.6028/" seems to be needed for this to build.  Make it normative (!).

FIPS 180 and 202 weren't marked as anything in your PR, @seanturner. Switching them back to informative since there's no actual requirement in this draft to implement SHA(KE), they're only used internally to SLH-DSA.
